sn22.90:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ sambahulā therā bhikkhū bārāṇasiyaṃ viharanti isipatane migadāye.
sn22.90:1.1.eng: At one time several senior mendicants were staying near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana.

sn22.90:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā channo sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito avāpuraṇaṃ ādāya vihārena vihāraṃ upasaṅkamitvā there bhikkhū etadavoca:
sn22.90:1.2.eng: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Channa came out of retreat. Taking a latchkey, he went from dwelling to dwelling, going up to the senior mendicants and saying,
sn22.90:1.2.comm: This is not the arahant Channa of MN 144:13.11 = SN 35.87.

sn22.90:1.3.pli: “ovadantu maṃ āyasmanto therā, anusāsantu maṃ āyasmanto therā, karontu me āyasmanto therā dhammiṃ kathaṃ, yathāhaṃ dhammaṃ passeyyan”ti.
sn22.90:1.3.eng: “May the venerable senior mendicants advise me and instruct me! May they give me a Dhamma talk so that I can see the teaching!”
sn22.90:1.3.comm: These events follow the Buddha’s passing, where he asked the Saṁgha to not advise Channa or instruct him (DN 16:6.4.1. Channa features often in the Vinaya as a monk who refuses correction and acts disrespectfully. The Sangha had already imposed an act of “ejection” (ukkhepanīyakamma) on him due to his persistent bad behavior, but that was still not enough (Kd 1:25.1.1). The brahmadaṇḍa was imposed at the First Council (Kd 1:1.12.1), upon which Channa finally saw the error of his ways.

sn22.90:2.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, therā bhikkhū āyasmantaṃ channaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn22.90:2.1.eng: When he said this, the senior mendicants said to Venerable Channa:

sn22.90:2.13.comm: This teaching, which omits “suffering”, is found at only one other place, where, as here, it was unsuccessful. The point is that trying to soft-pedal the Dhamma by omitting suffering is not going to work. See MN 35:4.6 and note.

sn22.90:3.11.pli: Sabbe saṅkhārā aniccā, sabbe dhammā anattā’ti.

sn22.90:3.12.pli: Atha ca pana me sabbasaṅkhārasamathe sabbūpadhipaṭinissagge taṇhākkhaye virāge nirodhe nibbāne cittaṃ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati nādhimuccati.
sn22.90:3.12.eng: And yet my mind does not leap forth, gain confidence, settle down, and become decided about the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.

sn22.90:3.14.eng: and keeps turning back to the thought:
sn22.90:3.14.comm: Mānasaṁ is accusative in the sense, “a thought”.

sn22.90:3.15.comm: The idiom atha ko carahi is consequential, “so who then …”

sn22.90:3.16.pli: Na kho panevaṃ dhammaṃ passato hoti.
sn22.90:3.16.eng: But that doesn’t happen for someone who sees the teaching.

sn22.90:3.17.pli: Ko nu kho me tathā dhammaṃ deseyya yathāhaṃ dhammaṃ passeyyan”ti.
sn22.90:3.17.eng: Who can teach me the Dhamma so that I can see the teaching?”

sn22.90:4.2.pli: “ayaṃ kho āyasmā ānando kosambiyaṃ viharati ghositārāme satthu ceva saṃvaṇṇito sambhāvito ca viññūnaṃ sabrahmacārīnaṃ, pahoti ca me āyasmā ānando tathā dhammaṃ desetuṃ yathāhaṃ dhammaṃ passeyyaṃ;
sn22.90:4.2.eng: “The Venerable Ānanda is staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery. He’s praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions. He’s quite capable of teaching me the Dhamma so that I can see the teaching.

sn22.90:4.3.pli: atthi ca me āyasmante ānande tāvatikā vissaṭṭhi.
sn22.90:4.3.eng: Since I have so much trust in Venerable Ānanda,

sn22.90:4.4.eng: why don’t I go to see him?”

sn22.90:4.5.pli: Atha kho āyasmā channo senāsanaṃ saṃsāmetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena kosambī ghositārāmo yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhiṃ sammodi …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā channo āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.90:4.5.eng: Then Channa set his lodgings in order and, taking his bowl and robe, set out for Kosambī. He went to see Ānanda in Ghosita’s Monastery, exchanged greetings with him, and told him what had happened. Then he said,

sn22.90:5.1.pli: “Ekamidāhaṃ, āvuso ānanda, samayaṃ bārāṇasiyaṃ viharāmi isipatane migadāye.

sn22.90:5.2.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, āvuso, sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito avāpuraṇaṃ ādāya vihārena vihāraṃ upasaṅkamiṃ;

sn22.90:5.4.pli: ‘ovadantu maṃ āyasmanto therā, anusāsantu maṃ āyasmanto therā, karontu me āyasmanto therā dhammiṃ kathaṃ yathāhaṃ dhammaṃ passeyyan’ti.

sn22.90:5.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, maṃ, āvuso, therā bhikkhū etadavocuṃ:

sn22.90:5.13.pli: Sabbe saṅkhārā aniccā, sabbe dhammā anattā’ti.

sn22.90:6.8.pli: Sabbe saṅkhārā aniccā, sabbe dhammā anattā’ti.

sn22.90:6.9.pli: Atha ca pana me sabbasaṅkhārasamathe sabbūpadhipaṭinissagge taṇhākkhaye virāge nirodhe nibbāne cittaṃ na pakkhandati nappasīdati na santiṭṭhati nādhimuccati.

sn22.90:6.13.pli: Na kho panevaṃ dhammaṃ passato hoti.

sn22.90:6.14.pli: Ko nu kho me tathā dhammaṃ deseyya yathāhaṃ dhammaṃ passeyyanti.

sn22.90:7.2.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho āyasmā ānando kosambiyaṃ viharati ghositārāme satthu ceva saṃvaṇṇito sambhāvito ca viññūnaṃ sabrahmacārīnaṃ, pahoti ca me āyasmā ānando tathā dhammaṃ desetuṃ yathāhaṃ dhammaṃ passeyyaṃ.

sn22.90:7.3.pli: Atthi ca me āyasmante ānande tāvatikā vissaṭṭhi.

sn22.90:7.5.eng: “May Venerable Ānanda advise me and instruct me! May he give me a Dhamma talk so that I can see the teaching!”

sn22.90:7.7.pli: karotu me, āyasmā ānando dhammiṃ kathaṃ yathāhaṃ dhammaṃ passeyyan”ti.

sn22.90:8.1.pli: “Ettakenapi mayaṃ āyasmato channassa attamanā api nāma taṃ āyasmā channo āvi akāsi khīlaṃ chindi.
sn22.90:8.1.eng: “I’m already delighted with Venerable Channa. Hopefully you’ve opened yourself up and severed your hard-heartedness.
sn22.90:8.1.comm: Channa has given up resentment towards his fellow monks, as described in the five kinds of hard-heartedness (MN 16:3.1).

sn22.90:8.3.eng: You are capable of understanding the teaching.”

sn22.90:8.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmato channassa tāvatakeneva uḷāraṃ pītipāmojjaṃ uppajji:
sn22.90:8.4.eng: Then right away Channa was filled with lofty rapture and joy,

sn22.90:8.5.eng: “It seems I’m capable of understanding the teaching!”

sn22.90:9.1.pli: “Sammukhā metaṃ, āvuso channa, bhagavato sutaṃ, sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ kaccānagottaṃ bhikkhuṃ ovadantassa—
sn22.90:9.1.eng: “Reverend Channa, I heard and learned in the presence of the Buddha his advice to the mendicant Kaccānagotta:
sn22.90:9.1.comm: Ānanda is referring to SN 12.15. See there for notes.

sn22.90:9.2.pli: dvayanissito khvāyaṃ, kaccāna, loko yebhuyyena atthitañceva natthitañca.
sn22.90:9.2.eng: ‘Kaccāna, this world mostly relies on the duality of existence and non-existence.

sn22.90:9.3.pli: Lokasamudayaṃ kho, kaccāna, yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passato yā loke natthitā, sā na hoti.
sn22.90:9.3.eng: But for one who truly sees the origin of the world with right understanding, the concept of non-existence regarding the world does not occur.

sn22.90:9.4.pli: Lokanirodhaṃ kho, kaccāna, yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passato yā loke atthitā, sā na hoti.
sn22.90:9.4.eng: And for one who truly sees the cessation of the world with right understanding, the concept of existence regarding the world does not occur.

sn22.90:9.5.eng: This world is for the most part shackled by getting involved, grasping, and insisting.

sn22.90:9.6.pli: taṃ cāyaṃ upayupādānaṃ cetaso adhiṭṭhānābhinivesānusayaṃ na upeti na upādiyati nādhiṭṭhāti ‘attā me’ti.
sn22.90:9.6.eng: But if—for all that getting involved and grasping, mental fixation, and insistence and underlying tendency—they do not get attracted, grasp, and fixate on the thought, ‘my self’,

sn22.90:9.7.pli: Dukkhameva uppajjamānaṃ uppajjati, dukkhaṃ nirujjhamānaṃ nirujjhatīti na kaṅkhati na vicikicchati.
sn22.90:9.7.eng: they’ll have no doubt or uncertainty that what arises is just suffering arising, and what ceases is just suffering ceasing.
sn22.90:9.7.comm: As at MN 35:21.2, the inadequate teaching that omits suffering is corrected by a teaching that specially emphasizes it.

sn22.90:9.8.eng: Their knowledge of this is independent of others.

sn22.90:9.9.eng: This is how right view is defined.

sn22.90:9.11.eng: “All does not exist”: this is the second extreme.

sn22.90:9.12.pli: Ete te, kaccāna, ubho ante anupagamma majjhena tathāgato dhammaṃ deseti—
sn22.90:9.12.eng: Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One teaches by the middle way:

sn22.90:9.14.eng: Choices are a requirement for consciousness. …

sn22.90:9.15.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.

sn22.90:9.16.eng: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, choices cease. …

sn22.90:9.17.eng: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”’”

sn22.90:10.1.pli: “Evametaṃ, āvuso ānanda, hoti yesaṃ āyasmantānaṃ tādisā sabrahmacārayo anukampakā atthakāmā ovādakā anusāsakā.
sn22.90:10.1.eng: “Reverend Ānanda, this is how it is when you have such venerables as spiritual companions to advise and instruct you out of kindness and sympathy.

sn22.90:10.2.pli: Idañca pana me āyasmato ānandassa dhammadesanaṃ sutvā dhammo abhisamito”ti.
sn22.90:10.2.eng: And now that I’ve heard this teaching from Venerable Ānanda, I’ve comprehended the teaching.”

sn22.91:1.1.comm: This discourse is also found at SN 18.21 and SN 22.71.

sn22.91:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā rāhulo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā rāhulo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.91:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Rāhula went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn22.91:1.3.pli: “kathaṃ nu kho, bhante, jānato kathaṃ passato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā na hontī”ti?
sn22.91:1.3.eng: “Sir, how does one know and see so that there’s no I-making, mine-making, or underlying tendency to conceit for this conscious body and externally for all signs?”

sn22.91:2.1.pli: “Yaṃ kiñci, rāhula, rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ rūpaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
sn22.91:2.1.eng: “Rāhula, one truly sees any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.91:2.2.eng: One truly sees any kind of feeling …

sn22.91:2.5.pli: yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā …pe…
sn22.91:2.5.eng: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.91:2.6.pli: sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.

sn22.91:2.7.pli: Evaṃ kho, rāhula, jānato evaṃ passato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā na hontī”ti.
sn22.91:2.7.eng: That’s how to know and see so that there’s no I-making, mine-making, or underlying tendency to conceit for this conscious body and externally for all signs.”

sn22.92:1.1.comm: This discourse is also found at SN 18.22 and SN 22.72.

sn22.92:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā rāhulo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.92:1.2.eng: Seated to one side, Rāhula said to the Buddha:

sn22.92:1.3.pli: “kathaṃ nu kho, bhante, jānato kathaṃ passato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānāpagataṃ mānasaṃ hoti vidhāsamatikkantaṃ santaṃ suvimuttan”ti?
sn22.92:1.3.eng: “Sir, how does one know and see so that the heart is rid of I-making, mine-making, and conceit for this conscious body and externally for all signs; and going beyond discrimination, it’s peaceful and well freed?”

sn22.92:2.1.pli: “Yaṃ kiñci, rāhula, rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā …pe… yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ rūpaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā anupādā vimutto hoti.
sn22.92:2.1.eng: “Rāhula, when one truly sees any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self,’ one is freed by not grasping.

sn22.92:2.2.eng: One truly sees any kind of feeling …

sn22.92:2.5.pli: yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā anupādā vimutto hoti.
sn22.92:2.5.eng: When one truly sees any kind of consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self,’ one is freed by not grasping.

sn22.92:2.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, rāhula, jānato evaṃ passato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānāpagataṃ mānasaṃ hoti vidhāsamatikkantaṃ santaṃ suvimuttan”ti.
sn22.92:2.6.eng: That’s how to know and see so that the heart is rid of I-making, mine-making, and conceit for this conscious body and externally for all signs; and going beyond discrimination, it’s peaceful and well freed.”

sn22.93:1.2.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, nadī pabbateyyā ohārinī dūraṅgamā sīghasotā. Tassā ubhosu tīresu kāsā cepi jātā assu, te naṃ ajjholambeyyuṃ; kusā cepi jātā assu, te naṃ ajjholambeyyuṃ; pabbajā cepi jātā assu, te naṃ ajjholambeyyuṃ; bīraṇā cepi jātā assu, te naṃ ajjholambeyyuṃ; rukkhā cepi jātā assu, te naṃ ajjholambeyyuṃ. Tassā puriso sotena vuyhamāno kāse cepi gaṇheyya, te palujjeyyuṃ. So tatonidānaṃ anayabyasanaṃ āpajjeyya. Kuse cepi gaṇheyya, pabbaje cepi gaṇheyya, bīraṇe cepi gaṇheyya, rukkhe cepi gaṇheyya, te palujjeyyuṃ. So tatonidānaṃ anayabyasanaṃ āpajjeyya.
sn22.93:1.2.eng: “Suppose, mendicants, there was a mountain river that flowed swiftly, going far, carrying all before it. If wild sugarcane, kusa grass, reeds, vetiver, or trees grew on either bank, they’d overhang the river. And if a person who was being swept along by the current grabbed the wild sugarcane, kusa grass, reeds, vetiver, or trees, it’d fall apart, and they’d come to ruin because of that.
sn22.93:1.2.comm: A similar use of palujjati is at Bhāgavata Purāṇa 8.2.20.

sn22.93:1.3.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano ariyānaṃ adassāvī ariyadhammassa akovido ariyadhamme avinīto, sappurisānaṃ adassāvī sappurisadhammassa akovido sappurisadhamme avinīto
sn22.93:1.3.eng: In the same way, an unlearned ordinary person has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen true persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the true persons.

sn22.93:1.4.pli: rūpaṃ attato samanupassati, rūpavantaṃ vā attānaṃ; attani vā rūpaṃ, rūpasmiṃ vā attānaṃ.
sn22.93:1.4.eng: They regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.

sn22.93:1.5.comm: The root luj (Sanskrit ruj) is used early to mean “fracture, break, smash”, as at Rig Veda 10.152.3, “fracture the jaws of Vṛtra”. See SN 35.82:2.3 and note.

sn22.93:1.6.eng: and they come to ruin because of that.

sn22.93:1.10.pli: viññāṇaṃ attato samanupassati, viññāṇavantaṃ vā attānaṃ; attani vā viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇasmiṃ vā attānaṃ.
sn22.93:1.10.eng: consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.

sn22.93:1.12.eng: and they come to ruin because of that.

sn22.93:1.24.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.94:1.2.pli: “Nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, lokena vivadāmi, lokova mayā vivadati.
sn22.94:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I do not dispute with the world; it is the world that disputes with me.

sn22.94:1.3.pli: Na, bhikkhave, dhammavādī kenaci lokasmiṃ vivadati.
sn22.94:1.3.eng: When your speech is in line with the teaching you do not dispute with anyone in the world.

sn22.94:1.4.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, natthisammataṃ loke paṇḍitānaṃ, ahampi taṃ ‘natthī’ti vadāmi.
sn22.94:1.4.eng: What the astute deem as not existing, I too say does not exist.

sn22.94:1.5.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, atthisammataṃ loke paṇḍitānaṃ, ahampi taṃ ‘atthī’ti vadāmi.
sn22.94:1.5.eng: What the astute deem as existing, I too say exists.
sn22.94:1.5.comm: The Buddha rejects the metaphysical views of absolute, eternal existence and annihilation (SN 12.15:3.1, SN 12.48:2.2), but he asserts the reality of that which is conditioned and impermanent, namely the aggregates. The Buddha was neither a substantialist nor an idealist; he was a relational phenomenologist.

sn22.94:2.1.pli: Kiñca, bhikkhave, natthisammataṃ loke paṇḍitānaṃ, yamahaṃ ‘natthī’ti vadāmi?
sn22.94:2.1.eng: And what do the astute deem as not existing, which I too say does not exist?

sn22.94:2.2.pli: Rūpaṃ, bhikkhave, niccaṃ dhuvaṃ sassataṃ avipariṇāmadhammaṃ natthisammataṃ loke paṇḍitānaṃ; ahampi taṃ ‘natthī’ti vadāmi.
sn22.94:2.2.eng: Form that is permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable.

sn22.94:2.6.pli: viññāṇaṃ niccaṃ dhuvaṃ sassataṃ avipariṇāmadhammaṃ natthisammataṃ loke paṇḍitānaṃ; ahampi taṃ ‘natthī’ti vadāmi.
sn22.94:2.6.eng: Consciousness that is permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable.

sn22.94:2.7.pli: Idaṃ kho, bhikkhave, natthisammataṃ loke paṇḍitānaṃ; ahampi taṃ ‘natthī’ti vadāmi.
sn22.94:2.7.eng: This is what the astute deem as not existing, which I too say does not exist.

sn22.94:3.1.pli: Kiñca, bhikkhave, atthisammataṃ loke paṇḍitānaṃ, yamahaṃ ‘atthī’ti vadāmi?
sn22.94:3.1.eng: And what do the astute deem as existing, which I too say exists?

sn22.94:3.2.pli: Rūpaṃ, bhikkhave, aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ atthisammataṃ loke paṇḍitānaṃ; ahampi taṃ ‘atthī’ti vadāmi.
sn22.94:3.2.eng: Form that is impermanent, suffering, and perishable.

sn22.94:3.4.pli: viññāṇaṃ aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ atthisammataṃ loke paṇḍitānaṃ; ahampi taṃ ‘atthī’ti vadāmi.
sn22.94:3.4.eng: Consciousness that is impermanent, suffering, and perishable.

sn22.94:3.5.pli: Idaṃ kho, bhikkhave, atthisammataṃ loke paṇḍitānaṃ; ahampi taṃ ‘atthī’ti vadāmi.
sn22.94:3.5.eng: This is what the astute deem as existing, which I too say exists.

sn22.94:4.1.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, loke lokadhammo, taṃ tathāgato abhisambujjhati abhisameti;
sn22.94:4.1.eng: There is a worldly phenomenon in the world that the Realized One understands and comprehends.
sn22.94:4.1.comm: The Pali is loke lokadhammo. It seems useful to keep the overly-literal rendering “worldly phenomenon in the world” to maintain the pattern of the discourse. Here it alludes to the idea that it is the world because it “wears away” (SN 35.82:2.3).

sn22.94:4.2.pli: abhisambujjhitvā abhisametvā taṃ ācikkhati deseti paññapeti paṭṭhapeti vivarati vibhajati uttānīkaroti.
sn22.94:4.2.eng: Then he explains, teaches, asserts, establishes, clarifies, analyzes, and reveals it.

sn22.94:5.1.pli: Kiñca, bhikkhave, loke lokadhammo, taṃ tathāgato abhisambujjhati abhisameti, abhisambujjhitvā abhisametvā ācikkhati deseti paññapeti paṭṭhapeti vivarati vibhajati uttānīkaroti?
sn22.94:5.1.eng: And what is that worldly phenomenon in the world?

sn22.94:5.2.pli: Rūpaṃ, bhikkhave, loke lokadhammo taṃ tathāgato abhisambujjhati abhisameti.
sn22.94:5.2.eng: Form is a worldly phenomenon in the world that the Realized One understands and comprehends.

sn22.94:5.3.pli: Abhisambujjhitvā abhisametvā ācikkhati deseti paññapeti paṭṭhapeti vivarati vibhajati uttānīkaroti.
sn22.94:5.3.eng: Then he explains, teaches, asserts, establishes, clarifies, analyzes, and reveals it.

sn22.94:6.1.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, tathāgatena evaṃ ācikkhiyamāne desiyamāne paññapiyamāne paṭṭhapiyamāne vivariyamāne vibhajiyamāne uttānīkariyamāne na jānāti na passati tamahaṃ, bhikkhave, bālaṃ puthujjanaṃ andhaṃ acakkhukaṃ ajānantaṃ apassantaṃ kinti karomi.
sn22.94:6.1.eng: This being so, what can I do about a foolish ordinary person, blind and sightless, who does not know or see?

sn22.94:6.5.pli: viññāṇaṃ, bhikkhave, loke lokadhammo taṃ tathāgato abhisambujjhati abhisameti.
sn22.94:6.5.eng: Consciousness is a worldly phenomenon in the world that the Realized One understands and comprehends.

sn22.94:6.6.pli: Abhisambujjhitvā abhisametvā ācikkhati deseti paññapeti paṭṭhapeti vivarati vibhajati uttānīkaroti.
sn22.94:6.6.eng: Then he explains, teaches, asserts, establishes, clarifies, analyzes, and reveals it.

sn22.94:7.1.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, tathāgatena evaṃ ācikkhiyamāne desiyamāne paññapiyamāne paṭṭhapiyamāne vivariyamāne vibhajiyamāne uttānīkariyamāne na jānāti na passati tamahaṃ, bhikkhave, bālaṃ puthujjanaṃ andhaṃ acakkhukaṃ ajānantaṃ apassantaṃ kinti karomi.
sn22.94:7.1.eng: This being so, what can I do about a foolish ordinary person, blind and sightless, who does not know or see?

sn22.94:8.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, uppalaṃ vā padumaṃ vā puṇḍarīkaṃ vā udake jātaṃ udake saṃvaḍḍhaṃ udakā accuggamma ṭhāti anupalittaṃ udakena;
sn22.94:8.1.eng: Suppose there was a blue water lily, or a pink or white lotus. Though it sprouted and grew in the water, it would rise up above the water and stand with no water clinging to it.

sn22.94:8.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, tathāgato loke jāto loke saṃvaḍḍho lokaṃ abhibhuyya viharati anupalitto lokenā”ti.
sn22.94:8.2.eng: In the same way, though I was born and grew up in the world, I live having mastered the world, unsullied by the world.”
